Hebrew origin; typically indeclinable in Latin (but some texts use genitive 'Israelis')

notes: An interrogative adverb expressing duration or extent of time
Literally 'to trip by the sole' (sub + planta). Used both literally and metaphorically.
Greek loanword (Χριστός). In Christian Latin, always capitalized.
Often used metaphorically for descendants or the Word of God in Scripture.
Literally 'to gird before' (prae + cingo). Often used for putting on armor.
Frequently used in military contexts. Not to be confused with 'proelium' (alternative spelling).
Often implies a forceful or legal demand (cf. English 'requisition'). Present participle 'requirens' agrees in case/number with its subject.
Derived from 'adjuvare' (to help). Often used in Christian Latin for divine helpers (e.g., 'Adjutor meus es tu' = 'You are my helper').
Deponent verb (passive forms with active meaning). Common in formal greetings.
From 'per-' (through) + 'maneo' (stay). Often implies lasting through time.

Often used for formal storytelling or reporting.
Derived from 'lex' (law) + 'lator' (bringer).
Imperative singular is 'pere' (not 'per').
